results.title: A Day in the Life of Captain Cook
results.brief_description:
A reenactment of Captain Cook and his crew hitting land after a treacherous arrival to a new island, later named Botany Bay.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: Get in the picture at ACMI - Open House 25-7-04
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘In the Picture’ - a free taste of our popular Screen Adventures Program. Members of the public were invited to walk on and act up in front of ACMI’s blue screen ‘film genre’ sets.

results.title: Talks: a Natimuk Primary School animation
results.creator_credit: Dave Jones and Natimuk Primary School
results.brief_description: A collaboration between students from Natimuk Primary School and animation artists Dave Jones funded as part of the Arts Victoria Artists in Schools program. Hand drawn crayon drawings are animated and Combined with recorded soundgrabs from the kids to make an engaging sequence of simple, colourful character studies!

results.title: The Nature of paradise
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Lucinda Gamble
results.brief_description:
Three women - Trish Molloy (artist), Monique La Fontaine (artist), Sharon Wiggan (law student) - tell their stories, each from a personal perspective, of their relationship and connection to the Western Australian north-west coastal town of Broome. Trish and Monique are travellers who have separately found their way to Broome and stayed and Sharon is an Aboriginal Australian who was brought up in Broome, left to study in Perth and who has now returned home to Broome. The documentary explores each woman’s emotional and spiritual attachment to the town, to their surrounding environment and their kinship with the people of Broome and with each other. Evocative and beautifully photographed by Veronica Iacono, and sensitively scripted and directed by Lucinda Gamble, “The Nature of paradise” is stunningly rich in images and colour, of reds and blues, of the earth, sky and the ocean and is accompanied by an ambient musical soundtrack, “Free diving” written and performed by Lorrei
Coffin. Interspersed throughout the documentary are images of both Trish and Monique’s paintings which reflect their transitional journey to this place called “paradise”.

results.title: Cross my heart
results.creator_credit: Andrew Wiseman, Jocelyn Moorhouse, David Swann and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: Two women attending a friend’s funeral who died from cancer vow to quit smoking, cold turkey. There are obstacles in their way however, including a sister who has just split up with her partner, her son in tow. They instil a no smoking policy in the house with penalties for those who break the rules. Features salient points about the ill effects of smoking and the side effects you can expect when quitting. Cast includes: Marilyn O’Donnell, Parthena Amanatidis, Tamasin Ramsay, Brian Nankervis.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Wiseman, Jocelyn Moorhouse, David Swann and Open Channel Productions

results.title: Et cetera. Season 2. Episode 7 [The State Library. Melbourne Cup handover. Tumbarumba]
results.brief_description:
Northern Access Television produced this episode of the
series “Et cetera” featuring a visit to the State Library of
Victoria and an interview with Melinda Dundas - Public
Affairs Officer, who talks of the services available to
residents and tourists, and multicultural, regional and youth oriented initiatives. Interviewer Suzana Talevski
also speaks to Librarian Des Cawley. Justine Isard reports
from the Windsor Hotel where the handover of the Melbourne Cup by the Hardy Brothers to the Victorian Racing Club (VRC) is taking place. Includes footage of the cup’s production. Phillip Taylor speaks to percussion group
Tumbarumba. Presented by David McLauchlan.

results.title: Transit: SteamRail workshops
results.creator_credit: Northern Access TV, David McLauchlan and Michael Costello
results.brief_description:
This episode of ‘Transit’ is the ninth in a series of ten-quarter hour episodes produced by Northern Access Television in 1998.
‘Transit’ was a series of Community TV programs produced about Melbourne’s and Victoria’s Public Transport System and Transport Museum Groups by Michael Costello, a former Melbourne Tram Conductor. Other episodes included episodes on the Bendigo and Ballarat Tramway Museums, the Melbourne Transit Band, the Tramcar Restaurant and many others. In the 1998 series, various members of Northern Access TV assisted in the production of the programs. The programs were all made using volunteers from Northern Access TV on Mini DV cameras.
This episode looks at the SteamRail Workshops, located in the former Newport Railway Workshops. It consists of an interview where David McLauchlan interviews Keith Finlay, secretary of SteamRail Victoria Inc. This non-profit volunteer based association aims to preserve Victoria’s steam powered rail heritage and keep examples of them running for public tours to many destinations on Victoria’s Rail Network. In addition to preserving the days of steam-powered trains, the group also has sections that are dedicated to preserving Diesel and Electric rolling stock as well. During the interview, we see examples of the work undertaken on the carriages and associated equipment.

results.title: Globalisation 101
results.creator_credit: Kim Beamish, Alex Kelly and SKA TV
results.brief_description: Globalisation 101 looks at the impacts of corporate-lead globalisation on workers, indigenous people and the environment both locally and globally. It traces the history of transnational organisations such as the World Bank and International Monetary Fund and charts the origins of third world debt.

results.title: Noise TV - Darebin Music Feast
results.brief_description:
In this episode of Noise TV we join host Shane Laffy, who introduces us to Mayor Vince Fontana for the opening of the Darebin Music Feast, a community celebration inviting and encouraging us to participate in finding expression through the arts, sharing and benefiting from the diverse cultural experiences that enrich our very own continually developing and unique Australian style and identity.
Featuring an original music score by composer Simon Moore with TheNoise performers and performances on this show include, quirky street horn players, Five Angry Men, the infectious dance drum rythms of the Tumbarumba Samba School & Latin Soulfire Dancers, the amazing Soukous Ba Congo,featuring the soulful vocals of King Bell, Kurdish expert instrumentalist Dursam Akar, a tribute concert for pioneer Greek composer Thymios Stathoulopoulos, featuring vocals from mother and daughter Yiota and Maria Stathoulopoulos, and the ever popular sound of Janine Marshall and Neil Robe.
